facts.text: Raja Rajinder Chand filed six suits in 1940 in Court of Subordinate Judge, Kangra for declaration of ownership of all pine trees on defendants' lands in Nadaun Jagir.

anchor.surface_text: He brought six suits in the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Kangra for a declaration that he was the owner of all pine  chil-pinus longifolia  trees standing on the lands of the defendants within the said Jagir and for a permanent injunction restraining the latter from interfering with his rights of ownership and extraction of resin from the said trees. He also claimed specified sums as damages for the loss caused to him from the tapping of pine trees by different defendants from March 24, 1940, up to the date when the suits were brought.

facts.text: Defendants are adna maliks (inferior landlords) who pleaded ownership and possession of lands and trees thereon.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants, who are the adnamaliks  inferior landlords , pleaded that they were the owners in possession of the lands on which the trees stood, that the trees were their property, and that the plaintiff had numberright to the trees number had he ever exercised any right of possession over them.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Kangra dismissed suits on July 24, 1941, holding plaintiff failed to prove ownership and suits barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge, who dealt with the suits in the first instance, held that the present appellant had failed to prove his ownership of the trees. He further held that the suits were barred by time. On the question of damages, he held that if the appellants claim to ownership of the trees were established, some of the defendants in four of the suits would be liable for small amounts of damages.

facts.text: District Judge, Hoshiarpur reversed Subordinate Judge on ownership and limitation, allowed appeals on July 31, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Raja Rajinder Chand then preferred appeals from the judgment and decrees of the learned Subordinate Judge, and the appeals were heard by the learned District Judge of Hoshiarpur. The latter reversed the finding of the ,learned Subordinate Judge on the question of ownership and held that the present appellant had established his right to the trees in question. He also reversed the finding of the learned Subordinate Judge on the question of limitation, but accepted his finding as to damages.

facts.text: Punjab High Court on Dec 30, 1949 reversed District Judge on ownership, agreed on limitation, dismissed suits.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants then preferred second appeals to the Punjab High Court. On the main question as to whether the present appellant had been able to establish his right to the trees, the learned Judges of the High Court differed from the learned District Judge and, agreeing with the learned Subordinate Judge, held that the present appellant bad number been able to establish his right to the trees.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeals Nos. 196-201 of 1953 from High Court certificate under sections 109 & 110 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 196 to 201 of 1953. Appeals from the judgment and decrees of the Punjab High Court dated December 30, 1949, in Civil Regular Appeals Nos. 1567, 1568, 1569, 1570, 1573 an 1574 of 1942 arising out of the decrees dated July 31, 1942, of the Court of the District Judge, Hoshiarpur in Appeals Nos. 104/35 of 1941- 42,101/32 of 1941, 103/34 -of 1941/42  15/73 of 1941, 102/33 of 1941/42 and 120 of 1941 arising out of the decrees dated July 24, 1941, of the Court of Subordinate Judge, 4th Class, Kangra in Suits Nos. 544, 548, 545, 547, 546 and 549 of 1940.

facts.text: Suit lands in Badhog and Jasai tappas of Nadaun Jagir, Kangra district.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, the suit lands lie in Badhog and Jasai tappas companyprised within the Jagir of Nadaun in the district of Kangra.

facts.text: Raja Sansar Chand, last independent ruler of Kangra, died in 1824.

anchor.surface_text: The last independent ruler of Kangra was Raja Sansar Chand who died in the year 1824.

facts.text: Raja Jodhbir Chand, son of Raja Sansar Chand, granted Nadaun Jagir by Maharaja Ranjit Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Maharaja Ranjit Singh came to Nadaun, and Jodhbir Chand gave his two sisters to the Maharaja. Jodhbir Chand was then created a Raja, with Nadaun and the surrounding companyntry as his Jagir.

facts.text: British Sanad granted to Raja Jodhbir Chand on October 11, 1848, renewing earlier grant.

anchor.surface_text: He obtained a Sanad from the British Government in 1846 A companyy of that Sanad was number available, but a companyy of a Sanad granted on October 11, 1848, which renewed and clarified the earlier Sanad, was produced and exhibited on behalf of the present appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Sanad of 1848 grants only land revenue (Jama Rs. 26,270), not rights to pine trees.

anchor.surface_text: We agree therefore with the High Court that on a true and proper companystruction of the Sanad, it is impossible to spell out of its terms a grant in favour of Raja Jodhbir Chand of the right to all pine trees on cultivated and proprietary lands.

facts.text: Wajib-ul-arz entries in 1892-93 (Ex P-5), 1899-1900 (Ex P-6), 1910-15 (Ex P-4) state pine trees belong to Raja.

anchor.surface_text: We have in these cases to deal with the entries made in OBriens Settlement  1892-93 , Andersons Settlement  18991900 , and the Settlement of Messrs Middleton and Shuttleworth  1910- 15 .

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Wajib-ul-arz entries do not establish surrender of sovereign right to pine trees by Government.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, it would be an unwarranted stretching of the presumption to hold that-the entries in the Wajib-ul-arz make out a grant of a sovereign right in favour of the Raja to do so would be to hold that the Wajib-ul-arz creates a title in favour of the Raja which it obviously cannot.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses appeals, holds appellant failed to establish ownership of pine trees.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, we hold that the appellant has failed to establish his claim to the pine trees, and the decision of the High Court is companyrect. The appeals fail and are dismissed.

facts.text: Damages claimed for tapping from March 24, 1940 to suit filing.

facts.text: Limitation not barred, as per District Judge and High Court findings, not contested in Supreme Court.

holdings.text: The appellant has not succeeded to the sovereign rights of the independent rulers of Kangra.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court held, in agreement with the learned Subordinate Judge, that the present appellant could not claim the sovereign rights of Raja Sansar Chand who was an independent ruler of Kangra. For this finding they gave two reasons firstly,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Raja Jodhbir Chand was illegitimate son; rights ended with Sikh annexation; he got only revenue assignment from Maharaja Ranjit Singh and British.

holdings.text: The Sanad dated October 11, 1848 granted only land revenue (jama) and not the right to all pine trees on cultivated and proprietary lands.

anchor.surface_text: We agree therefore with the High Court that on a true and proper construction of the Sanad, it is impossible to spell out of its terms a grant in favour of Raja Jodhbir Chand of the right to all pine trees on cultivated and proprietary lands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sovereign grants construed strictly in favour of sovereign; terms mention jama/revenue only; conditions limit to revenue collection; no mention of trees.

holdings.text: Sovereign grants are to be construed most favourably for the Sovereign.

anchor.surface_text: It is, we think, well settled that the ordinary rule applicable to grants made by a subject does not apply to grants made by the sovereign authority and grants made by the Sovereign are to be construed most favourably for the Sovereign.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well settled rule with limited relaxations (obvious intention, consideration, validity); applied to Sanad.

holdings.text: The entries in the Wajib-ul-arz do not establish a grant or surrender of sovereign right to pine trees in favour of the Raja.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, it would be an unwarranted stretching of the presumption to hold that-the entries in the Wajib-ul-arz make out a grant of a sovereign right in favour of the Raja to do so would be to hold that the Wajib-ul-arz creates a title in favour of the Raja which it obviously cannot.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wajib-ul-arz records existing customs, cannot create title; presumption under s.44 rebutted; no unambiguous surrender; confusion in entries.

holdings.text: The Wajib-ul-arz entries do not show surrender or relinquishment of sovereign right to chil trees on proprietary and cultivated lands.

anchor.surface_text: The question-before us is as to the true scope and legal effect of these entries. Do they establish a grant of the right to chil trees or, what is the same thing, a surrender

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entries record customs not sovereign grants; no basis in Sanad or history; Jamabandis show no restriction; prior complaints contradict.

holdings.text: The appellant has failed to establish his claim to the pine trees; appeals dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, we hold that the appellant has failed to establish his claim to the pine trees, and the decision of the High Court is correct. The appeals fail and are dismissed.

precedents.citation: Vajesingji Joravarsingji v. Secretary of State for India 1 1924 L.R. 51. I.A. 357, 360.

anchor.surface_text: It is pertinent to quote here the following observations of Lord Dunedin in Vajesingji Joravarsingji v. Secretary of State for India 1  When a territory is acquired by a sovereign State for the first time that is an act of State. It matters not how the acquisition has been brought about. It may be by conquest, it may be by cession following on treaty, it may be by occupation of territory hitherto unoccupied by a recognised ruler. In all cases the result is the same. Any inhabitant of the territory can make good in the municipal courts established by the new sovereign only such rights as that sovereign has, through his officers, recognised. Such rights as he had under the rule of predecessors avail him nothing.

precedents.case_name: Vajesingji Joravarsingji v. Secretary of State for India
precedents.cited_proposition: Acquisition of territory by a sovereign is an act of State; pre-existing rights are not enforceable unless recognized by the new sovereign.
precedents.cited_holding: Any inhabitant of the territory can make good in the municipal courts established by the new sovereign only such rights as that sovereign has, through his officers, recognised. Such rights as he had under the rule of predecessors avail him nothing.

precedents.citation: Rajah Venkata Narasimha Appa Row Bahadur v. Rajah Narayya Appa Row Bahadur 1 1879 L.R. 7 I.A. 38, 48.

anchor.surface_text: Taking the most favourable view for the appellant, the entries in the Wajib- ul-arz in these cases can be said to express the views of certain revenue authorities as to the rights of the Raja or the intention of Government but the views of the revenue authorities as to the effect or construction of a grant or the intention of Government in respect of a grant, do not conclude the matter or bind the civil Courts.  See Rajah Venkata Narasimha Appa Row Bahadur v. Rajah Narayya Appa Row Bahadur 1  . The same comments apply to the Wajib-ul-arz of 1899-1900  Ex. P-6  and of 1910-15  Ex. P-4  . They no doubt say that the pine trees on the lands comprised within the Khatas of adna-maliks are the property of the Raja Sahib.

precedents.case_name: Rajah Venkata Narasimha Appa Row Bahadur v. Rajah Narayya Appa Row Bahadur
precedents.cited_proposition: Views or opinions of revenue authorities regarding the construction or intention of a grant do not bind civil courts.

precedents.citation: Dakas Khan v. Ghulam Kasim Khan 1 A.I.R. 1918 P.C. 4.

anchor.surface_text: A large number of decisions in which entries of the Wajib-ul-arz or the Riwaji-i-am and the value to be given to them were considered, have been cited before us. In some of them, entries in the Wajib-ul-arz were accepted as correct and in others they were not so accepted, notwithstanding the statutory presumption attaching to the entries under s. 44 of the Punjab Land-Revenue Act, 1887. We do not think that any useful purpose will be served by examining those decisions in detail. The legal position is clear enough. As was observed by the Privy Council in Dakas Khan v. Ghulam Kasim Khan 1 , the Wajib-ul-arz, though it does not create a title, gives rise to a presumption in its support which prevails unless the presumption is properly displaced

precedents.case_name: Dakas Khan v. Ghulam Kasim Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: Wajib-ul-arz does not create title but raises a presumption that prevails unless properly displaced.
precedents.cited_holding: the Wajib-ul-arz, though it does not create a title, gives rise to a presumption in its support which prevails unless the presumption is properly displaced

precedents.citation: Gurbakhsh Singh v. Mst. Partapo 1 1921 I L.R. 2 Lah. 346.

anchor.surface_text: It is also true that the Wajib ul-arz being part of a revenue record is of greater authority than a Riwaji-i-am which is of general application and which is not drawn up in respect of individual villages  Gurbakhsh Singh v. Mst. Partapo 1  . Whether the statutory presumption attaching to an entry in the Wajib-ul-arz has been properly displaced or not must depend on the facts of each case. In the cases under our consideration, we hold, for the reasons already given by us, that the entries in the Wajib-ul-arz with regard to the right of the Raja in respect of chil trees standing on cultivated and proprietary lands of the adna-maliks, do not and cannot show any existing custom of the village, the right being a sovereign right nor do they show in unambiguous terms that the sovereign right was surrendered or relinquished in favour of the Raja.
